Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Joseph Spraker
Proposal Number: 1612169

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Joseph Spraker is "Bacteria in Fungi in Plants: How intimate microbial interactions mediate plant disease." The host institutions for this fellowship are the University of Arizona and the University of California - Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientists at these institutions are Dr. A. Elizabeth Arnold and Matthew Traxler, at each respective institution.

The goal of this project is to investigate the interactions of fungi (endophytes) associated with plant leaves, and the bacteria that live within these fungi (endohyphal bacteria). Plant microbiomes are complex communities consisting of bacteria and fungi. The interactions between these microbes are increasingly recognized to play important roles in plant health in both natural and agricultural settings. Although research has largely focused on microbial communities associated with soils and plant roots, it is increasingly apparent that the interactions between microbes colonizing plant leaves and shoots are similarly impacting plant health. To gain a better understanding of how above-ground microbes impact plant health, the Fellow is examining how their interactions impact resistance to plant pathogens, through the production of bioactive compounds. Integral to this work is the globally unique Robert L. Gilbertson Mycological Herbarium collection, housing >60,000 living fungal endophytes, which will be used as a source for a large-scale, systematic survey of endophylal bacteria (EB). Specifically, the Fellow is: 1) systematically characterizing EB associated with endophytic fungi and determining what environmental factors drive their interactions; 2) assessing the impacts of EB on fungal metabolism; and 3) evaluating the impact of EB on endophyte-plant-pathogen interactions. The results of this work will provide new insights into untapped strategies of sustainable disease management. Additionally, this work will improve the knowledgebase of the existing Robert L. Gilbertson Mycological Herbarium by documenting cryptic microbes already stored within the collection.

The Fellow is receiving training in cross-cutting research methodologies including next generation sequencing, computationally intensive meta-analyses, culture-based and plant-based bioassays, high throughput chemical analyses, and cutting-edge in planta metabolomics. These skills are facilitating the Fellow's professional goals of becoming a research professor at an academic institution. The Fellow is also improving his skills as an educator and bringing science to underrepresented groups. He is developing and implementing a unique high school outreach module focused on engaging underrepresented minorities in STEM with biological research, using art to facilitate learning and comprehension. This module is being developed within the framework of the award-winning science outreach program of the Arnold lab, and will also draw on the unique insights of the Arts and Environment Network, also housed at the University of Arizona.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacteria and fungi are microorganisms that routinely occupy overlapping niches in plant hosts. Some bacteria are also capable of colonizing fungal tissue, namely endohyphal bacteria (EHB), which can alter fungal phenotypes such as development and metabolic output. Shifts in fungal metabolism alter toxin and defensive compounds and may to influence how the host-fungus communicates with other neighboring microorganisms and potentially the plant host. Although these interactions  are ubiquitous in the environment, little is known of how EHB alter fungal metabolism. The results of this NSF award show that EHB can cause dramatic shifts in fungal metabolic output which may drive interactions with other microorganisms.

EHB-fungal co-cultures were used to examine how facultative EHB from different host-fungi alter fungal metabolism. Co-cultures were carried out in minimal media to encourage bacterial-fungal association, and were evaluated for differential metabolite production using high resolution liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HR-LCMS) experiments. Comparative metabolomics experiments showed that EHB from the native host fungus caused the most dramatic shift in overall metabolite profiles. Molecular networking of tandem mass spectrometry data showed that one of the putatively upregulated metabolites is an analog of a known antifungal compound, pestalotether. The transcriptional profiles of one focal bacterial-fungal interaction were assessed using RNAseq, and significant disregulation of secondary metabolite genes was confirmed with many of the  genes in the predicted pestalotether shown to be upregulated in response to the presence of the bacterium.

Many excellent undergraduate mentees from contributed to exciting research projects related to this award as well as their own independent research awards. Many of them were from diverse backgrounds that are often underrepresented in the sciences including women, Latin Americans, and Native Americans. Their many efforts have contributed to future publications, the development of open-source microscopy tools, and the advancement of our understanding of bacterial-fungal chemical communication. All of these researchers worked on multidisciplinary projects and learned to interact with diverse researchers with various research specialties.

The research aims of this award were complemented by the development of a science-art outreach program focused on introducing elementary and middle school students in Tucson, Arizona to the spectrum of natural symbioses including fungal-EHB encounters. This program was developed in collaboration with members of the Arts and Environment Network as well as volunteer undergraduate researchers from the University of Arizona, and incorporated hands-on and interactive science-art projects to help students engage with the material and communicate their understanding through orthogonal media, and thus encourage retention of concepts relating to symbioses. We also brought some of our activities to the Tucson Children’s Museum’s Family SciFest to get students of all ages to engage with microbial symbioses and better understand how these unseen interactions impact the daily live of humans.
